org.stripesstuff.stripersist
Class Stripersist

java.lang.Object
  org.stripesstuff.stripersist.Stripersist
All Implemented Interfaces:
ConfigurableComponent, Interceptor
@Intercepts(value={RequestInit,RequestComplete})
public class Stripersist
extends Object
implements Interceptor, ConfigurableComponent

Stripersist provides a simple way to use JPA in Stripes applications. It does this by providing Stripes with an EntityFormatter and EntityTypeConverter. The EntityFormatter finds the primary key for the entity and returns its value. The EntityTypeConverter takes a primary key value and retrieves the corresponding entity from the database.

To start using Stripersist with Stripes you need to do the following:

  1. Set up a JPA EntityManager. Your persistence.xml file should go in WEB-INF/classes/META-INF/. Instructions on how to do that are beyond the scope of this documentation but you can find more info in Sample Chapter 2 of Java Persistence with Hibernate. The relevant information starts on page 68 of the PDF.
  2. Add the Stripersist jar file to you WEB-INF/lib directory.
  3. Add org.stripesstuff.stripersist to the Extension.Packages parameter of your StripesFilter in web.xml

That's it! Now you should be able to use your entities as properties of your ActionBean and Stripes will handle the binding for you.

Author:
Aaron Porter

Field Detail

INIT_CLASSES_PARAM_NAME

public static final String INIT_CLASSES_PARAM_NAME
Parameter name for specifying StripersistInit classes in web.xml. This is optional; StripersistInit classes are also loaded via the Extension.Packages.

findEntities

protected static Set<Class<?>> findEntities(String jarName)
Finds and returns all classes that are annotated with Entity or MappedSuperclass. This code was taken from Stripes ResolverUtil and modified to suit our needs.

Parameters:
jarName -
Returns:
a set of entity classes

getEntityManagerFactory

public static EntityManagerFactory getEntityManagerFactory(String persistenceUnit)
Finds the EntityManagerFactory which is associated with the specified persistence unit. Normally you shouldn't use this class because Stripersist won't clean up any EntityManagers that you create.

Parameters:
persistenceUnit - the name of the persistence unit
Returns:
an EntityManagerFactory or null

getEntityManagerFactory

public static EntityManagerFactory getEntityManagerFactory(Class<?> forType)
Finds the EntityManagerFactory which is associated with the specified class. Normally you shouldn't use this class because Stripersist won't clean up any EntityManagers that you create.

Parameters:
forType - a class that the EntityManagerFactory knows how to handle
Returns:
an EntityManagerFactory

getEntityManager

public static EntityManager getEntityManager()
If Stripersist only knows about one EntityManager this is a convenient way to retrieve it. Keep in mind that if you use this and later decide to add another persistence unit you will have to go back and fix every call to getEntityManager() in your application.

Returns:
an @EntityManager

getEntityManager

public static EntityManager getEntityManager(String persistenceUnit)
Retrieves the EntityManager associated with the named persistence unit.

Parameters:
persistenceUnit - the name of the persistence unit
Returns:
an EntityManager or null

getEntityManager

public static EntityManager getEntityManager(Class<?> forType)
Retrieves an EntityManager that may be used with the specified type.

Parameters:
forType - a class that is handled by the EntityManager
Returns:
an EntityManager or null

requestInit

public static void requestInit()
Initializes request specific variables. Under normal circumstances this is called automatically but if you want to use Stripersist from your own threads you may call this as long as you remember to call requestComplete() when you are done (preferably from inside a finally block).

requestComplete

public static void requestComplete()
Rolls back current EntityTransactions and closes EntityManagers. Under normal circumstances this is called automatically but if you've called requestInit() from within your own thread you should make sure this is in a finally block so everything gets cleaned up.

intercept

public Resolution intercept(ExecutionContext context)
                     throws Exception
Called by Stripe's Interceptor system. We use it to perform initialization and cleanup at the start and end of each request respectively.

Specified by:
intercept in interface Interceptor
Throws:
Exception
